habitat_description:
Southwest/Great Plains:
Common bird of pinyon-juniper, pine, and mixed oak-pine forests (Guzy and Lowther 1997). Open coniferous or mixed coniferous-deciduous woodlands with brushy undergrowth, pinyon-juniper, pine-oak association and oak scrub (Guzy and Lowther 1997). Nests on low ridges with open stands of junipers (Guzy and Lowther 1997). Prefers trees with dense and stiff foliage; of relatively low statue and in dry environments (Johnsgard 1992). Breeds in pinyon-juniper woodlands in Colorado, especially in taller and denser woodlands (Andrews and  Righter 1992). Occasionally in other coniferous forest types adjacent to pinyon-juniper (Andrews and  Righter 1992). In Utah, preferred breeding habitats include dry oak slope, pinyon-juniper woodlands, open mixed woodlands, chaparral, dry coniferous and mixed woodlands with a brushy understory (Utah Conservation Data Center 2001). Prefers densely wooded areas over areas where trees are more widely spaced in Utah (Utah Conservation Data Center 2001). Inhabits juniper-pinyon-oak scrub on slopes, foothills, and canyons (NatureServe 2004). Winters uncommonly in cottonwood-willow and sycamore-mesquite associations in southwest Arizona (Phillips and Monson 1964).
In sw. Wyoming, prefers woodland with pinyon pine (Pinus edulis), north- and east-facing slopes, and understory vegetation approaching breast height (Pavlacky and Anderson 2001). In Monterey Co., CA, generally above 600 m in mixed oak-pine forests, found in mixture of oaks (canyon live oak [Quercus chrysolepis], coast live oak [Q. agrifolia], and interior live oak [Q. wislizenii]) among thick chaparral (such as manzanita [Arctostaphylos sp.] or blue buck-brush [Ceanothus ramulosus]), often with foothill pine (Pinus sabiniana) or ponderosa pine (P. ponderosa); burned-over areas often used for foraging (Roberson and Tenney 1993). In Santa Clara Co., CA, in canyon live oak forest at higher elevations of Santa Cruz Mtns., and broader range of more open habitats (manzanita forest, oak and buckeye [Aesculus] woodlands) in Diablo Range (W. G. Bousman pers. comm.). In White and Inyo Mtns., CA, at 2,050–2,880 m elevation in piñon-juniper and riparian vegetation, and above 3,000 m in mountain mahogany (Cercocarpus montanus) scrub within bristlecone pine–limber pine (Pinus aristata – P. flexilis) forest (Hall et al. 1991). In Marin Co., CA, occurs in relatively dry, open, mixed evergreen forests usually dominated by Douglas fir but generously mixed with coast live oak, canyon live oak, tanbark oak (Lithocarpus densiflorus), or other broadleaf evergreen trees, saplings, or shrubs; especially common in areas that have more continuous Douglas fir cover mixed with oaks and saplings along meadow edges or where firs (Abies spp.) grade into mixed or serpentine chaparral (Shuford 1993). In Santa Barbara Co., CA, in mixture of oaks and conifers (San Rafael Mtns.) and oak-madrone (Quercus-Arbutus) woodland (Santa Ynez Mtns.; Lehman 1994). In Chiricahua Mtns. of se. Arizona, oak-juniper woodlands of alligator juniper (Juniperus deppeana) , Chihuahuan pine (Pinus leiophylla), Mexican piñon pine (P. cembroides), Emory oak (Quercus emoryi) , and Arizona white oak (Q. arizonica) (Balda 1969)(quoted directly from Guzy and Lowther 2012). Winter range habitats are similar to breeding-range habitats; also in variety of forest, woodlands, scrub, and thickets (Am. Ornithol. Union 1983). In Arizona, found in cottonwood-willow and sycamore-mesquite (Platanus-Prosopis) associations (Monson and Phillips 1981). In California, oaks, particularly coast live oaks; occasionally in willows and cottonwoods along streams (Dunn and Garrett 1997)(quoted directly from Guzy and Lowther 2012).

Northwest:
Open coniferous or mixed coniferous-deciduous woodland with brushy undergrowth, piñon-juniper (Pinus-Juniperus) and pine-oak (Pinus-Quercus) associations, and oak scrub (Am. Ornithol. Union 1983). “Common” in w. Oregon in mix of Oregon white oak (Quercus garryana) and Douglas fir (Pseudotsuga menziesii); bigleaf maple (Acer macrophyllum) scattered in stand with understory of sapling oak and pine, hazelnut (Corylus cornuta), cherry (Prunus sp.), red alder (Alnus rubra), and madrone (Arbutus menziesii; Morrison 1982). Common in somewhat open areas with second growth of young conifers (w. Washington; S. F. Rathbun in Bent 1953); scattered, tall conifers with bushes (s. Oregon; Bowles 1902); chaparral such as deer brush, lilac (Syringa spp.), scrub oak (Quercus ilicifolia), and sometimes evergreens (s. California; W. K. Fisher in Chapman 1907); piñon belt (Nevada; Linsdale 1938). In s. Idaho, nests on low ridges with open stands of junipers (Burleigh 1972); similar preferences evident in nw. Colorado (Sedgwick 1987). In sw. Wyoming, prefers woodland with pinyon pine (Pinus edulis), north- and east-facing slopes, and understory vegetation approaching breast height (Pavlacky and Anderson 2001)(quoted directly from Guzy and Lowther 2012).
